review_title: Great benefits, good people, lots of politics though
pros: Great fringe benefits (used to be better, but are still pretty generous in comparison to the private sector), great energy working at a University and lots of opportunity for professional development/ability to take classes towards a bachelor's or master's degree if desired.  Slow and steady pay increases each year. Once you are in the system and your work ethic is known and appreciated, you are pretty much in and can move up (or around to different departments).  Internal people move around frequently and happily, it seems. Staff has ability to enjoy perks such as harbor cruises in the summer, discount tickets to various events, generous holidays, and don't forget snow days  : )
cons: Parking is relatively expensive and difficult to find for an area that is 1) not downtown Boston and 2)  not an extremely easy public transportation location (especially during non-peak hours--wait for shuttle can be annoying).  Wages are not the greatest, are often very middle-of-the-road.   Can be a very political place to work, and nepotism/politics/general playing favorites is a common theme in upper administration.   Always having to readjust to new leadership.

review_title: Great job after a slow start.
job_title: Engineering Intern in Fall River, MA
pros: Great Place for an internship, with the possibilities of working on a variety of projects.  The ATMC provides great opportunities to work with many start up companies of varying sizes.  They provide a great environment to do both theoretical research, but more importantly there are many real world projects that provide a great amount of experience.  Many of the projects and start up companies are working on cutting edge research in their respective fields.  The ATMC provides a good means of validating the classroom lessons in the real world.  My internship here has made me a far more employable individual.
cons: The start of my time at the ATMC was very slow.  It took several weeks before I was equipped with a computer or assigned to a project.  It was at least a month before I felt like I was doing anything of value for myself or the ATMC or their customers.  My first project was not very relevant to my interests or degree, and seemed to be a complete waste of time.  Management was unable to really provide any well defined task, and I was forced to spend a lot of time trying to find other things to do with my time.

review_title: Unique company that combines academic, industrial, and government biological research into one... for good and bad.
pros: Small company in quiet, remote part of Mattapan (yeah). Brand new buildings, giving everything a nice polished look. Respectable mission of creating treatments for infectious diseases the world over, and doing it for the greater good rather than profit. Good people, even managers. Manufacturing facilities are well maintained and they really seem to take health and safety seriously. If you work hard you can go far, despite lacking higher degrees.
cons: Highly resistant to change, especially the manufacturing department. Company has been going through a rough patch, and had a large layoff in Fall '11. This sent morale into a tailspin. Many projects seemed like busywork rather than being actually important. New revenue streams were needed, so they started doing contract work, which frequently have harsh deadlines. Being a company owned by UMass Medical School, it has the research standards of a govt. lab, the paperwork of an industrial manufacturing lab, and the politics of an academic lab.

review_title: MassBiologics - beware if you are not a scientist.
pros: Intelligent people and stimulating research work developing new products with lots of young people working in the labs.  A new building is being built for research which should be a big improvement over the existing lab building.  The Fill/Finish manufacturing equipment is very new and nearly state of the art (except for IT aspects) and there is plenty of free parking.  Vacation and benefits are very generous even if pay does not quite keep up.
cons: Senior Leadership is science not business oriented.  Reorganizations happen frequently and without notice to the people affected.  Performance reviews reflect politics rather than actual performance.  There is no adequate cost accounting system and decision-making is centralized in the extreme.  The company currently depends on royalties from the legacy product RSV and revenues from Td vaccine, but all the investment dollars recently have gone into new (failed, so far) products and Td market share is slipping.  RSV will be subject to future competition from other products and patent expiration.  The future looks grim without a successful new product.

cons: Needs improvement with resources and etc.

job_title: Human Resources Generalist in Shrewsbury, MA
pros: UMASS has a lot of good and competent people working there.  The benefits are very good; some salaries are also very good.  If you are on a 'hot' project, you get a lot of resources, assistance and attention (which is good and bad).  You can be at UMASS until you retire, if you continue to be a contributor with a good attitude.
cons: The practice of hiring political pals, with minimal qualifications at best, into senior/executive positions (and the inequality that creates at so many levels) really got to me after awhile.  It's also hard to be accepted as a committed fellow employee by the 'old guard' - those at UMASS  for 7-15+ years.   Professional development and career paths all depends on which department you are in - nothing  consistent for all employees.

review_title: Teaching assistant compensation and responsibilities similar to other universities
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: The experience you have as a teaching assistant depends primarily on who you're teaching for and the kind of guidance you get from the department. My experience with UMass was fine, and having the support while I finished my degree was great. The campus itself is in a beautiful location on the Boston Harbor, and there continue to be a lot of improvements to the buildings (including new buildings) all the time.
cons: Payment and reimbursements are part of a HIGHLY bureaucratic system. People are generally nice in the grad student office, but I had issues getting paid on several occasions. Small points, but the library doesn't have enough windows -- which is true of a lot of the older buildings on campus. I hope that they new buildings are being constructed with higher standards!

review_title: Crippled by association with U Mass Medical School
pros: The oldest biotech in Massachusetts with a unique legacy of innovation, public service covering all aspects of biotech from discovery to production of commercial product. A great place to see every aspect of the industry.
cons: Income from MassBiologics sales and royalties are supposed to be reinvested in the MassBiologics business, instead, the U Mass Medical school, appointed to oversee MassBiologics (previously part of the Department of Pubic Health) has illegally stolen tens of millions of dollars to prop up their own poorly managed budget while failing to fulfill their legal requirements to MassBiologics.  As a result development has been underfunded and the public service purpose of the organization subverted, leading to a failure to retain talent or develop new biologics in line with the intent of the statute.

- no path to promotion, your job is your job until you decide to go somewhere else
- talent not recognized
- staff ideas don't rise to the top; definitely a trickle down place
- there are also some people that are just riding it to retirement and impede people who want to make a difference
-lots of micro-management

pros:
Sheer size allows for opportunities to work in variety of fields,
If taking classes is your "thing," you get tuition waiver,
More holidays than the classic corporate environment because the Univ. follows an academic schedule,
Opportunity to improve skills through workplace learning
An academic year has a different ebb/flow to the pace of work,
Being around young people keeps you young AND on top of what's "current"
Cutting edge research.
You're helping shape the future "leaders" of our country--that's the purpose of education
Academia is a pretty easy-going work environment.
cons: If you want quick action, academia is not for you.   It's thoughtful and sometimes painfully slow to change or even make decisions.

review_title: I've been a student here for 3 years now, worked on campus for two years.
pros: It is an okay place to work at. People are mostly middle-aged, some of them hate their job, and some of them are really excited to be doing what they're doing. It's a vibrant community, you may meet people from all over the world and expand your horizons. By the end of the first year you'll probably remember that Haiti and DR are two states located on the same island. Compensation is fair enough.
cons: Sometimes, it's hard to get along with people who are very stubborn in their way to go a good job. They don't want to do better, they are not interested in delivering excellent work. They just want to do a good job.

review_title: don't work here if you don't need to
pros: The best reasons are:  discounted tuition, dress code, access to resources (library, gym, etc.).
cons: The campus is not attractive -- the buildings have no charm and the interiors are painted cement block walls -- even in the executive offices.  The co-workers -- non-faculty-- are divided into union and non-union with conflicting salary schedules and benefits.  The university is trying to rid itself of its union employees and it's very obvious why (lower pay and less benefits for non-union).  The co-workers are OK and usually helpful -- particularly HR and IT .  If you want to go to school at night, it's an OK environment and the discounted tuition can make up for the downside.

review_title: Don't appreciate the hard work of their employees
pros: It's a very intellectually stimulating environment, lots of research and some of the top researchers in the world so there's a great focus on learning and advancing medicine.  Also, the benefits are great.
cons: I don't believe the employees are all treated with the kind of respect expected for the amount of work effort demanded for this type of field.  Employees are expected to come in on weekends and holidays, fight through extreme weather to get to work under any circumstances.  Yet, they make employees pay for their parking; reviews and raises are not done and pay is fairly poor.

review_title: Nice to start but don't plan to stay
pros: Generous paid time off and sensitivity to work/ life balance.  Some flexible scheduling and a fringe benefits equal and in some cases better than other employers.
cons: Opportunities as few and you need to "play the game" to get ahead.  While senior management has the technical skills to accomplish the work their people skills are sorely lacking and it does not appear there are any programs in place to enhance these skills.  If you are of the "state employee" mindset and are comfortable getting plugged into a position with minimal advancement and opportunity for job growth this may be for you.

pros: If you can get a benefited position you'll be able to enjoy free classes, free tuition, and a stable job.
cons: The pay isn't competitive, little room for advancement, poor management that chooses to ignore; harassment claims, pest control, food safety issues, and in general good business practices. If you work here find a lawyer, you'll find laws being broken constantly so that upper management can cut corners.  It took almost 5 weeks for my first paycheck, and I was lucky, some of my colleagues have to wait 2 months for their first checks because of a massive bureaucracy.

pros: Nice work environment.  Pretty camps.  Nice students.
cons: Little opportunity for advancement of professionals.  Upper "management" all have PhD's.  For example a past President of the university system had a PhD in Physics.  Studying physics has little to do with managing an organization, yet they promote their own and PhD's ultimately only will answer to other people with PhD's as ultimately they are classist.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros:
The 20-hour TA position is a great deal. Tuition waiver plus the AMAZING health insurance is 95% free--extremely affordable. The other benefits, like the gym reimbursement, are incredible. The hours are reasonable--you often work less than 20 but get the standard pay no matter what. Tasks are very doable and the professors are happy to answer questions. Some are teaching and grading and some are grading only.

Be aware that while the position comes with a stipend and tuition waiver, you are still responsible for fees, which are typically $600-1200 per semester.
cons: It's not always clear how the TA assignments are made. The teaching + grading assignments are more work and responsibility but paid the same as the grading assignments.

job_title: R&D and Sales Manager in Santa Barbara, CA
pros:
It is an old, family owned company. The company has not aggressive strategies in marketing and R&D. Therefore I have a low stress position. 
I also have the privilege of define and manage most of my activities and be more efficient and productive.
cons: It is an old, family owned company. The CEO is old and resists major changes that are necessary for improving the products and also sales and marketing efforts.

review_title: Good experience as a graduate student research assistant
pros: As a research assistant I find I have plenty of resources for the job. The faculty are all respectful of us and will even assist us with our own research.
cons: It is a big state university and there are some bureaucratic issues that the student union has had to deal with, plus the number of graduate student fees keep growing.

review_title: Head Soccer Coach University of Massachusetts Women's Club Soccer
job_title: Head Soccer Coach in Auburn, MA
pros: Had a great group of talented young ladies to coach. Gained experience in leading a team and and staying organized. The University was more than helpful in gaining access to fields for practice and games as well as receiving payment.
cons: The conditions of the fields given to us were not always in the greatest condition. However my overall experience with the University of Massachusetts as a intramural referee and coach were more than satisfying.

review_title: If I knew what I know now, I never would have taken the job!
pros: Job stability and flexible hours
cons: No chance for career advancement (more of a job than a career), off-site location gets ignored by Worcester (no workshops, meetings, lack of communication), upper management fails to see that supervisors need training in how to supervise, most people are unhappy but stay because of job stability and hour flexability, people who should be fired are never fired

pros:
-Extremely understanding of academic responsibilities
-Never had a problem missing a shift, showing up late, or leaving early in order to fufill academic responsibilities 
-Flexible breaks
cons:
-Very uncomfortable work environment at times (very wet, steamy, and hot)
-Can be very stressful at busy times and when people don't show up (i.e. closing and in between course changes)
-Need to wear rubber boots, apron, and gloves unless you want to get absolutely soaked (sometimes these run out which can be a nightmare)

pros: People are friendly. Flexible hours for the most part. Probably a good place to work at if you're more focused on  retirement but I can't recommend it for young people.
cons: Terrible and inexperienced management. They tend to take credit for your work. They like to outsource or buy expensive products that ends up not being used in order to justify their accomplishments for the year. Unions make most people lazy and not work to their full potential. Management likes to ask you verbally and avoid sending you emails for work outside your job description so there won't be paper trails.

pros: The university offers excellent opportunities for professional growth, training, and networking. Intellectual resources (faculty, libraries, staff) are easily accessible, and motivated and capable help (students, recent grads) is abundant. Quality of life is high.
cons: Although progressive attitudes are widespread, inequality is high, and senior faculty and upper-level administrators enjoy comfortable pay and benefits packages while most everyone else suffers. Junior faculty struggle under crushing workloads, staff and graduate students are often paid poorly, and high undergraduate tuition and fees burden recent grads with excessive debt.

pros: Great if you're looking for a 9-5 gig - everybody screeches out of there at 5pm! Also a good amount of vacation time and holidays. Benefits provided are also good.
cons: Leadership is pretty much nonexistent. Strategic plans are never fully constructed or adhered to, so everyone there just moves with whichever way the wind blows. There's also a sense of complacency...but they do need to get it together otherwise the for-profits will put them out of business.

pros: Decent health insurance, nice office space, good campus, HR services timely and helpful. Good environment to work and study. Good faculty and staff around.
cons: Remote location. As a result not great opportunities for spouse to find a job in a given ares.  For faculty staff workers (which postdocs are considered to be) no good benefits in terms of for example using the campus tennis courts and such.

review_title: Good Place to work but more of a good first job.
pros:
This job was my work study for 2 years of my college career. My boss was very very nice, she's one of the sweetest women in the world. They are very understanding when personal issues come up. It's more of a starting job where you do basic officework like filing paperwork, and making copies.
I enjoyed working there.
cons: No way to work you way up (dead end job), no bonuses or benefits.

review_title: It was good in terms of gaining experience and learning from the mistakes of others and oneself
pros: My job gave me the opportunity to meet other students and faculty across the campus. It also gave me an insight as to what was occurring culturally and otherwise on campus.
cons: Sometimes work tended to be a bit much but that is expected depending on who you work with, your job expectations and the time in the semester.

pros: The job was okay, the supervisors were generally friendly and willing to help. They were great at accommodating my student schedule and allowed me to change shifts each semester.
cons: The managers at the Blue Wall ("head honchos") were rude and very demanding to student staff. Many full time employees were repeatedly laid off when classes were out of session, leading to poor morale. The pay was atrocious.

review_title: They treat employees especially RA's poorly, if you have multiple offers RUN FAR
pros: In the beginning it's a good place to learn that's all
cons:
No overtime but work assigned requires more than 8 hours regularly
No room to grow and barely development opportunities
Is it even legal to put in 40hours every week when I regularly work more than that.
Every good person leaves once they get a chance because it is a terrible place to be. They suck everything out of you until you have nothing else left. RUN AWAY IF YOU CAN!

review_title: Don't like it but it's the best in the area
pros: Working for UMASS Medical School is very challenging but it has great benefits and an excellent work-life balance. It's why most people still work here. For me the pros are ten minutes away from where i live, more paid holidays that any other employer in the area, great compensation compared to the rest of the companies in the area, extremely flexible work life balance which includes working from home and a very generous benefits package and retirement plan.
cons:
Where to begin?

This company is completely politics driven and there is no accountability. 
There is no growth and career advancement.
Folks in I.T. withhold information, are very difficult to work with, don’t communicate changes and they never plan ahead. There isn’t a clear process on how to proceed on a daily basis. Everyone works in reactive and not in proactive mode. Don’t fix it until its broken type of mentality. 
There’s absolutely no communication between I.T. departments, so if something changes many hours are wasted to figure out the problem that was caused by the non-communicated change.
Yearly reviews with your manager are a joke and there is no feedback at all. 
There is no recognition and praise when you put in long hours and after you have fixed a major problem caused by a non-communicated change. Most people don't care or don't want to know what you did and why you stayed late. If you do this often and keep staying late it's then expected. 
Management and Senior Management are unqualified for the job. They still work here because it’s a State Agency and they know Key people.
What’s also a slap to the face is how promotions and raises are given. It seems that only the incompetent and lazy are promoted. 
This place also lack basic professionalism standards that are required in the workplace. 
There is no respect between employees because the whole place is politic-driven.
That’s the best I can do with the character limit imposed by Glassdoor.com. To fully review this company you’ll need to write a book. 
I wouldn’t recommend this company to anyone except those who have a family and look for a balanced work-life relationship. 
The only thing I have to look forward to everyday is when it’s time to go home, when it’s Friday or when I take my vacation.

pros: Excellent university with outstanding students, faculty and staff.  Excellent quality of education with many fields of study.  The University is diverse, rich in culture, and supportive of academic endeavors. Excellent benefits and vacation package.
cons: There is a lot of micro-management in some departments, and overall, very top-heavy managerially speaking.  Communication is little to non-existent at times even when crucial to job performance.

pros: I really enjoyed working at UMass as a student employee. My co-workers and my supervisor were easygoing, but still productive. It was the first time I worked in an office environment and it was a good introduction to working with a large organization.
cons: There weren't any major cons. I did have to teach myself some things, but that helped me become a better problem solver.

review_title: Overall, it was a good place to work and everyone is willing to help you when you need it.
job_title: Research Laboratory Technician in Worcester, MA
pros: You learn very much about how a research lab operates, as well as learning many techniques and skills along the way. The PI's are very understanding about the work you perform, and most are flexible with scheduling.
cons: The pay is sub-par, but that is expected from an academic institution (unless you are a professor). The administration is also sometimes very slow to help you with problems that may arise (such as obtaining access to different facilities).

review_title: Faculty cherished, all others second class.
pros: Flexible, competitive compensation, not particularly demanding environment.   The good news is that all employees are treated equally.  The bad news is that all employees are treated equally.
cons:
Only PhD's, specifically scientific, are promoted to senior non-academic management positions, despite zero experience in the particular department or discipline.
Beurocratic traffic jams delay projects.  
Very few comprehensive systems in place to support campuswide communication, calendars, information distribution, institutional research, etc...  Feels like everyone starts every project from scratch.
Merit based pay system exists only in theory.

pros: The working hours are very flexible and you get access to a lot of university resources that you n use for your career advancement. The management is also very helpful.
cons: The pays are a little on the low side and the university is currently in a hiring freeze so not many full time employees are being hired these days

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Amherst Center, MA
pros:
- Academia
- If you have a car, university is 2-3 hours from New York City and Boston
cons:
It depends on your adviser/supervisor for a graduate research assistant. I was overworked and underpaid as graduate student. I did not learn anything of value from my adviser, and I was not allowed to take classes because it takes time away from my work.

- Overworked (Contract 4 hrs, worked much more)
- Underpaid (Did not get paid more for working more)
- University is a middle of nowhere (for a person coming from an urban city)

review_title: It's place for these people required a good balance between work and life.
pros: It have everything a state university should have.  You will have your personal life except the excellent environment for work.
cons: It has trouble of self-promotion for some people since the school style is that you take care of yourself and we do our jobs.  So it is a good place for retirement.

review_title: Wonderful Place to Develop and Grow
pros: Amazing opportunities for growth. Peers are always supporting each other. Great benefits and ample time off. Great work/life balance
cons: The finances at Umass is a disaster! In trying to develop the college, they are really invested creating beautiful new spaces at the expense of the staff. Layoffs have been used as a tool to find money to build resulting in overextending the current staff.

pros: As a resident assistant, you really learn a lot about yourself and learn to become a great leader and great team player. It is also an amazing experience to meet others as well as grow personally and professionally.
cons: The job can be a bit overwhelming when you are a full time student. Also, you must deal with obnoxious residents and drunkenness nearly every weekend.

pros: Nice area for doing research, quiet, yet driving distance to two major cities, boston and new york. There are some smart students.
cons: The compensation is not the greatest. Not enough funding opportunities. Known for being a party school, i.e. some students are simply not that diligent workers, you may have a hard time teaching them.

pros: The pay is competitive with other part time on campus jobs, it is very flexible, the staff is friendly, and if you work hard you can move up.
cons: There will be times when you don't have much to do because of a lack of activity in the computer lab.

review_title: As TA for your grad department, you gain insights and connections
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Amherst, MA
pros: Grad school assistant-ships are great if you like to teach and are comfortable with content. Wonderful for your resume if you are looking to teach at university level. As it is a union job, you have grate hourly salary, stability and protection from potentially abusive faculty
cons: Be sure that you have the time and are willing to be invested in your students.

pros: Solid Pay, Great Coworkers, Other than this I just don't have that many good things about cvs care mart or retail in general
cons: Expect to work a lot of long hours. Corporate doesn't give stores enough hour to run on; more work and less time to get tasks done.

pros: Good resources for IT and some students actually care about their jobs.
cons: Many students and staff are clearly their to get credit or get paid, respectively and there is a lot of politics controlling communication in that Department.

review_title: The workplace was professional and the employer is very clear about his instructions
pros: Clear instructions were given to the teaching assistants for their next lesson plan, though previous experience is suggested to ease into presentation skills
cons: While the working environment was very good, I felt that the material could be handled better in terms of reviewing earlier material. It's necessary that students have previous knowledge of statistics, but students do not enter the class with perfect memories.

review_title: Decent Place to Work with Caveats
pros: Decent place to work, excellent work-life balance, great benefits including access to retirement savings (traditional pension and newer deferral plans), paid time off, employee discounts, life/disability and other insurance products.
cons: Lack of strategic direction at all management levels, difficulty getting things done in consensus driven environment, need to be a self-motivator, hard to move around horizontally or vertically, very political environment.

pros: flexibility with working hours, also u mass has a great benefits package and good overall projects to work on, along with good departments.
cons: some of the downsides include politics and the who you know game. I think the pros do outweigh the cons however

review_title: Most resourceful state university at an amazing price.
pros: Resources under all departments: Academics, transportation, events, student organizations, advisors, study abroad options, job opportunities, and financial aid options. The design of the campus itself makes getting around easy too.
cons: Too many choices, which can become overwhelming. There's also lots of construction going on because of their 50 year plan on giving the 150 year old university a beautiful tune-up and additions.

review_title: Decent university for research and study

1, Good academic reputation
2, Excellent working environment if you find the right advisor
3, Convenient network services and library

pros: Progressive management, diversity, unionized employees make for a worker-friendly environment.  The surroundings are clean, safe, and urbane; nice place to raise a family.
cons: Underfunded and undervalued by state; there seems to be money for new buildings but not for resources to support employees.

pros: Friendly people, Less pressure, good pay. This place has flexible work schedule and during vacation periods only very little things to do.

Freedom to work independently
Nice campus

Research group is incredibly exclusive - if you have only one year of cell culture experience you're rejected...two years is good enough though

job_title: Business Systems Analyst in North Dartmouth, MA

Most people are awesome. IT group is the best. Decent perks.

cons: Some people are the bane for the rest the campus. Talent is not considered. Experience outranks everything. Your ideas matter but are not considered most of the time. People in high positions do not value your opinion and sometimes their policies are stupid.

review_title: Great diversity of students and most are committed, hard working students who are here to learn.
pros: Union for part time faculty, pay is on the higher end than most university courses, staff and faculty are generally friendly and supportive.

pros: The people working there were very nice. While I did not really talk to them, I never had much of a problem with anyone working there.

review_title: Great coworkers, great campus, meaningful work
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Amherst, MA

Fun projects that help the education of others.
Kind, smart coworkers.
Very flexible working conditions.
Human resources returns calls promptly and offers useful help.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Amherst, MA

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Amherst, MA

ability to be creative
have a bi weekly pay on top of housing while you are an undergrad
respect from peers and professional staff memebers
